headline: Marion native Jeremiah Workman enters statewide political arena
author: Andrew Carter
sentences: According to the poll of 1,066 likely GOP primary voters conducted Feb. 1-4, DeWine received backing from 40.9% of respondents with Renaci (22.8%) and Blystone (20.2%) locked in a tight battle, but well behind the governor.

Workman said while he agreed with their shared conservative ideals, what really drew him to get involved in the campaign was Blystone's "work ethic" and the fact that he didn't perceive Blystone as just a "politician."

It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure in the last couple of years with all the mandates and the shutdowns, people's livelihoods have been lost and a lot of small businesses are never going to open again.
While their message resonates with residents of Ohio's rural areas, Workman said he believes they've been well received in urban and suburban areas, too.
Blystone, who characterizes himself as a "constitutional conservative," is one of four men seeking the GOP nomination in the May 3 primary election.
"So people, I think, are finally waking up and we're going to have record turnout in this primary because of the state that we're in right now."
Blystone said Delaware City Council member Lisa Keller introduced the two men last December as he was in the process of seeking a running mate.
Following 15 years in the nation's capital, he and his wife decided it was time to return home to Ohio and they settled in the Richwood area.
"I honestly think people, regardless of whether they're in the city or out in the country, people are just sick and tired of what's going on.
Blystone and Workman presented their message to local residents on Friday evening during a campaign stop at a local farm in the Morral area.
"When I got home, it didn't take long to look around and figure that things weren't exactly in a good state here," Workman said.
Following graduation from North Union High School, he served in the United States Marine Corps, seeing combat action in Iraq.
"You can have $40 million in the bank, you can't win the hearts and minds and the spirit of the people of Ohio," he said.
And I feel that's why so many people have clung to us, because they can look at us and say, 'They're regular people.'"
But he indeed finds himself in the fray as the running mate to Ohio Republican gubernatorial candidate Joe Blystone.
We never wanted to be politicians, but we didn't like what was being pushed out there to vote for again and again.
The most recent Ohio governor's race statewide poll shows DeWine with a comfortable lead over Renaci and Blystone.
We're trying to bring rights back to the people here in Ohio and do things the right way for the right reasons."
"I met Jeremiah and we had a conversation and then I told him I'd like to meet his whole family," Blystone said.
"I said, 'You know what, I fought for our country in Iraq; I'm willing to fight for all of Ohio,'" Workman said.
I've never been one to come to the table to complain about something, but I wanted to be part of the solution."
Workman said despite the recent poll results, he and Blystone "have a movement right now that money can't buy."
"I met his wife and children and we had some more conversations and I just felt that he was the right person.
A native of Marion, Workman said he and his family moved to Richwood when he was in the fifth grade.
After leaving the Marines, Workman moved to the Washington, D.C., area and worked in the IT field.
Workman said the Ohio he left and the state he returned to were quite different in his estimation.
We were tired of going out and holding our noses and having to vote for the lesser of two evils.
Workman noted that it didn't take long for him to come to a decision to join the campaign.
"They want somebody that'll represent them that looks and talks and is like them.
Mike DeWine, former Ohio Congressman Jim Renaci, and former state Rep. Ron Hood.
Jeremiah Workman said he never intended to become involved in politics.
"Our message hasn't changed no matter where we go," Workman said.
"Joe and I will tell everybody we're not career politicians.
He would stand up for everything that you and I believe in."
"And that's what we're doing.
The field includes Gov.
He was a fighter.
